title: 103_hr2396
content:
The Act titled "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to provide financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. The Act allows depository institutions to disclose financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. State agencies can only use the information for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. Individuals can seek civil damages against a state for unauthorized disclosure by its officers or employees. If a State officer or employee discloses a financial record of an individual in violation of the law, the individual can sue the State for damages in federal court. There is no liability if the disclosure was made in good faith but based on an incorrect interpretation of the law. Damages in such cases would be the greater of $1,000 per unauthorized disclosure or the actual damages suffered by the individual. The defendant found liable for unauthorized disclosure of a financial record may be liable for the greater of $1,000 per act or the actual damages plus punitive damages in cases of willful or gross negligence. Additionally, costs of the action are included. Definitions for "depository institution" are provided in the section. Definitions for "depository institution," "financial record," and "State child support enforcement agency" are provided in this section. State child support enforcement agencies are granted access to consumer reports in child support cases. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity is established or acknowledged by the consumer, and the agency provides written notice and certification to the consumer reporting agency. The State agency can obtain a consumer report if certain requirements are met, and a State child support enforcement agency is defined as an agency that administers a program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE SUPPORT. The text discusses the inclusion of health care coverage in child support orders as mandated by amendments to the Social Security Act. It outlines procedures for ensuring coverage of health care costs for children in accordance with state guidelines and expediting the resolution of noncompliance allegations. The text discusses the requirement for states to establish guidelines for health care coverage in child support orders under the Social Security Act. It mandates a streamlined process to meet minimum standards set by the Secretary for the coverage of children's health care costs. The Secretary must establish regulations with minimum standards for guidelines providing health care coverage for children in child support orders. This includes the contents of the order, responsibility for costs, health insurance provisions, denial of coverage, and penalties for non-compliance by insurance providers. The Secretary must establish regulations with minimum standards for guidelines providing health care coverage for children in child support orders, including insurance information, coverage denial circumstances, penalties for non-compliance, and considerations for changes in parents' circumstances. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to issue proposed and final regulations within specific timeframes to implement amendments related to child support guidelines. Additionally, dependent health insurance provided due to successful enforcement may be included in the Incentive Payments Program under the Social Security Act. Amendment to the Social Security Act allows for the inclusion of dependent health insurance provided through successful enforcement of support orders in the Incentive Payments Program. The amount collected is determined by the savings to the State from providing health insurance to the children. Regulations must be issued within six months to implement these changes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prescribe regulations within 6 months to implement the amendment allowing for the inclusion of dependent health insurance in the Incentive Payments Program. Additionally, a study will be conducted to determine incentives for States to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses. A report on this study is due within 12 months of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will report on a study regarding noncustodial parents' obligations to cover children's health and dental expenses within 12 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORTS ON STATE COMPLIANCE WITH TIME LIMITS FOR CHILD SUPPORT ASSISTANCE. Amends the Social Security Act to include compliance by states with established standards. 

SEC. 6. WAGES WITHHELD BY EMPLOYERS FOR CHILD SUPPORT OBLIGATIONS MUST BE PAID TO STATE WITHIN 10 DAYS; LATE PAYMENT PENALTY IMPOSED ON EMPLOYERS. Amendment to the Social Security Act requires employers to pay withheld wages for child support obligations to the state within 10 days. Failure to do so incurs a $1,000 penalty to be used for state plan operations. Effective immediately upon enactment, applicable to wages paid thereafter. The amendments to the Social Security Act require employers to pay withheld wages for child support obligations to the state within 10 days. The effective date of these amendments is upon enactment, and they apply to wages paid thereafter. State plans may delay compliance if legislation is required. State plans are not considered non-compliant with child support requirements if they fail to meet additional requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the state legislature's session following the enactment of the Act. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is treated as a separate regular session. SEC. 7. NATIONAL PARENT LOCATOR NETWORK. The Social Security Act is amended to expand the Parent Locator Service, establishing a national network for child support enforcement across states. This network allows states to locate absent parents, access records from other states and federal sources, and identify multiple child support orders involving the same parent. The Parent Locator Service is expanded to create a national network for child support enforcement. This network allows states to access federal sources and records from other states to locate absent parents and identify multiple child support orders. Requests for information can be processed online or in batches, with a 48-hour turnaround time for broadcasted information. The national network for child support enforcement allows states to access federal sources and records from other states to locate absent parents and identify multiple child support orders. Requests for information have a maximum 48-hour turnaround time for broadcasted information. Access to court information is facilitated by having a computer terminal in each court. HR 2396 IH----2
